cal guns, 2 × {{convert|18|in|mm|abbr=on}} [[torpedo tube]]s |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} The first '''USS ''Chauncey'' (DD-3)''' (originally "Destroyer No. 3") was a [[Bainbridge class destroyer|''Bainbridge''-class]] [[destroyer]] in the [[United States Navy]] named for [[Commodore (United States)|Commodore]] [[Isaac Chauncey]]. ==Construction== ''Chauncey'' was launched on 26 October 1901 by [[Neafie and Levy Ship and Engine Building Company]] of [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]]. She was sponsored by Mrs. M. C. S. Todd and placed in reduced commission on 20 November 1902. ''Chauncey'' placed in reserve on 2 December 1902 and received full [[ship commissioning|commission]] on 21 February 1903. [[Lieutenant]] Stanford Elwood Moses was placed in command and ''Chauncey'' reported to the [[United States Fleet Forces Command|Atlantic Fleet]]. ==Pre-World War I== ''Chauncey'' served with the Coast Squadron until 20 September 1903, when she was transferred to the [[United States Asiatic Fleet|Asiatic Fleet]] and left [[Key West]] for the Orient on 18 December. After sailing by way of the [[Suez Canal]], she arrived at [[Cavite]] to join the force representing US interest in the Far East as it cruised in the [[Philippines]] during winters and off [[China]] during summers. Aside from the period of 3 December 1905-12 January 1907, when she was in reserve at Cavite, ''Chauncey'' continued this service until the entrance of America into [[World War I]]. ===Sinking=== The destroyer sailed from Cavite on 1 August 1917 for [[convoy]] escort duty in the eastern [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]], based at [[St. Nazaire]], France. On 19 November, while about {{convert|110|mi|km|abbr=on}} west of [[Gibraltar]] on escort duty, ''Chauncey'' was rammed by the [[United Kingdom|British]] merchantman SS ''Rose'' as both ships steamed in war-imposed darkness. At 03:17, ''Chauncey'' sank in {{convert|9000|ft|m|abbr=on}} of water, taking to their death 21 men including her [[Captain (naval)|captain]], [[Lieutenant commander (United States)|Lieutenant Commander]] [[Walter E. Reno]]. 70 survivors were picked up by ''Rose'', and carried to port. ==USS Chauncey in literature== The novel [[Delilah (novel)|''Delilah'']] was written by a survivor of ''Chauncey'', Marcus Goodrich, and is a fictional account based on his experience serving aboard ''Chauncey'' as an enlisted man. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{DANFS|http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/c7/chauncey-i.htm}} {{Bainbridge class destroyer}} {{coord missing|Atlantic Ocean}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chauncey (Dd-3)}} [[Category:Bainbridge-class destroyers]] [[Category:World War I destroyers of the United States]] [[Category:Ships built in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Ships built by Neafie and Levy]] [[Category:Ships sunk in collisions]] [[Category:World War I shipwrecks in the Atlantic Ocean]] [[Category:1901 ships]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 1917]]
